body: On 19th Street in Brooklyn, where Donald Schoenholt has his factory, industrial odors abound. Depending on the wind, the dark tang of ink from the printing plant next door might mingle with the fumes of solvent and paint from the signmaker up the street or the auto-body shops along Third Avenue. A constant olfactory drone of diesel exhaust
title: Cup of Kafka? Coffee Roaster Cited for Coffee Smell

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose public policy agenda has been eclipsed lately by the city's fiscal woes and the threat of a transit strike, is planning to shift some of his attention this week to the physical condition of New York City, particularly its housing. In the first of two major speeches on the subject, Mr. Bloomberg tomorrow will lay
title: Mayor Envisions Housing Revival Unmatched Since the 80's

body: ON the surface, New York has been transformed; Times Square, for example, has been squeakily scrubbed from neon rathole to Mickey Mouse Land. But the city still has a scabby underbelly that bristles with a jittery electricity that evokes the shadow world of noir: certain deserted subway stations after midnight; stygian bars without signs;
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; New York Noir

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. Opera ''IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA.'' The New York City Opera has established an identity as a company that discovers and gives opportunities to emerging singers. Two young vocalists make their
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

author: E-mail: anemona@nytimes.com
body: IN a New York City too often battered by crime and barely a year past Sept. 11, it may be heartening to realize that the Beltway sniper is a quintessentially suburban phenomenon. Every time he strikes, he parks his light-colored van near a highway with an easily accessible escape route. He prefers mall parking lots. Mass transit may be vulnerable
title: COPING; At a Nester's Paradise A Suburban Nightmare Feels Near

body: WHEN David Graham, a 38-year-old painter, gave up a studio carved out of an old diner in Williamsburg in 1997, 6 years into a 10-year lease to spend a year in Montreal, he figured he would have little difficulty duplicating it when he returned a year later. ''There was still a lot of space available, so I didn't think it would be a big deal,'' he
title: Artists Canvassing for Space

body: In an ambitious attempt to liberate Manhattan from traffic congestion, the Bloomberg administration will try to turn 10 Midtown streets into express routes by banning turns from them during weekdays when traffic is heaviest. The no-turn zones will be in effect Monday to Friday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., starting Oct. 15. They will involve 10 streets
title: Turns From Midtown Streets Will Be Banned on Weekdays

body: Dancing in the Streets has produced site-specific programs in areas throughout New York City for 19 years. Many of the programs have been devoted to the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, and to Red Hook's vivid, checkered history. Joanna Haigood is the latest artist to respond to the neighborhood's haunting allure. And her ''Picture Red Hook,''
title: DANCE REVIEW; A Little Night Magic for the Past

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. Opera GLIMMERGLASS OPERA. This summer opera festival has become known for inventive productions, solid casts of young singers and repertory that tilts toward the unusual, all played in a comfortably intimate
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

author: Wendy Perron, the New York editor of Dance Magazine, is a senior fellow at the Vera List Center for Art and Politics at the New School.
body: AN abandoned grain elevator rises high above the docks of Red Hook, Brooklyn. With 54 joined silos, it looks like a pack of gigantic cement ladyfingers. During its heyday, from the 1920's through the 50's, bulk grain was weighed, cleaned and dried there by laborers who lived in the neighborhood. From Thursday through Saturday, in ''Picture Red
title: DANCE; Way Up High, Soaring, Floating, Diving, Dancing

body: FROM time to time, Duke Snider returns to Brooklyn. He and his wife, Bev, have friends out on Staten Island, and as he drives out along the Gowanus Expressway toward the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, he occasionally makes a detour to Bay Ridge, where he spent a lot of very good summers. ''The last six years or so, we rented the same house on Marine
title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Royalty Comes Home Again

author: Randy Kennedy is a reporter for the Metro section of The Times who writes the Tunnel Vision column.
body: IN two years of constant riding and writing about the New York subway, I have noticed something interesting: whenever people talk about their favorite stretches, they rarely talk about the sub part. Instead, they sing love songs to the other half of the system, where trains don't run through tunnels but atop trestles, above the streets, rattling
title: Trips; The F Train Rises

author: Michael Shapiro's next book, ''The Last Good Season: Brooklyn, the Dodgers and Their Final Pennant Race Together,'' is due out next year.
body: I was 4 years old when the Dodgers left Brooklyn, but unlike the team, I stayed. I never went to Ebbets Field. I never even saw it. I lived in Brooklyn until I was 21 and when I, too, finally left, I did so still believing that had the Dodgers not abandoned the borough for Los Angeles, Brooklyn would have been altogether different, not the flat,
title: MY BROOKLYN; The Team That's Filling the Void the Dodgers Left Behind

body: THE best moment is swooping south on the F.D.R. Drive, just before the Manhattan Bridge, when the highway elevates again and it is like you are in a little airplane taking off. The view unfolds just over the silver hood: the downtown skyline, the East River bridges, Governors Island, the harbor. It's best at sunset, of course, when the piers in
title: No Particular Place to Go

body: In its way, the Gowanus Canal had lately been slouching toward clarity. The 1.8-mile waterway in South Brooklyn had lain stagnant until 1999, when an old flushing mechanism was reactivated, bringing in fresh water from New York Harbor and reinventing the waterway as a haven for canoers and blue crabs. But in recent weeks the pump has stumbled,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; The Canal Reverts (Briefly) to Its Malodorous Past

body: Django Opening The Gypsy jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt was the inspiration for Django, a spacious two-story restaurant at 280 Lexington Avenue (46th Street) created by the group that owns Rain, Union Pacific and Calle Ocho. David Rockwell's modern design is dressed up with paisley shawls, carpets and curtains of beads. The food is basic brasserie
title: OFF THE MENU

body: IF you wanted an analysis of New York's decrepit waterfront, on Wednesday you had a choice. You could either listen to the governor of New Jersey deliver the keynote address at the Waterfront 2002 Conference, or you could go cruising on a catboat with William Kornblum. It wasn't all that hard a choice, especially if you knew Dr. Kornblum's
title: The Big City; Waterfront Could Still Be a Contender

body: Celebrating Surf and Turf The Beard Street Pier in Red Hook, Brooklyn, was historically a place to unload. And so it will be tomorrow, when families will be encouraged to shed troubles, put aside cares and dance the day away at the Red Hook Waterfront Arts Festival. Before the festivities, however, is a remembrance in Coffey Park. ''Our local
title: FAMILY FARE

body: A CENTURY ago, Carroll Gardens was a working-class neighborhood in Brooklyn, home to thousands of Irish immigrants. In the decades before World War II, the Irish moved out and first-generation Italians moved in. The neighborhood kept its Italian-American character for decades and to a large degree retains it still. But in recent years a new group
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Carroll Gardens; Area of Gardens and 19th-Century Charm

body: Today is not a good day to take a Sunday drive around Manhattan, according to traffic authorities. Various street closings and parking restrictions will be in place because of parades, street fairs and other events. A police spokesman said that several bus routes would be disrupted and that drivers should expect heavy delays most of the day,
title: A Lovely Day For a Drive? Maybe, Except In Manhattan

body: The former police officer who struck a pregnant woman and her family with his minivan after drinking beer for an entire day in Brooklyn last year was convicted yesterday of the most serious charges he faced -- four counts of second-degree manslaughter. The former officer, Joseph Gray, 41, faces up to 15 years in prison. Mr. Gray sat expressionless
title: Ex-Officer Guilty of Manslaughter In Crash Following Drinking Bout

body: Jurors in the trial of a former police officer charged with running down a pregnant woman and members of her family last August had a firsthand look yesterday at one final piece of evidence: the scene of the crash. The jurors were escorted to the busy intersection in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, by Justice Anne G. Feldman and a parade of lawyers and
title: Jury Sees Site Where Officer's Van Killed 4

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: The twin beams of light forming a nocturnal memorial to World Trade Center victims will go dark in mid-April as planned, but may be incorporated into a permanent memorial, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. ''When we first did it, a lot of the families of those we lost were against it, because they felt it would become the permanent
title: Talk of Ground Zero Tribute, as West Street Reopens

body: A Brooklyn councilman who was recently a contender for City Council speaker was charged yesterday with demanding a $1.5 million break on a real estate deal from a developer in exchange for supporting the multimillion-dollar renovation of a waterfront warehouse in his district. The councilman, Angel Rodriguez, a Democrat, represents the Red Hook
title: Brooklyn Councilman Is Charged in an Extortion Scheme

body: ATTRACTIONS AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This weekend, the Hayden Planetarium presents ''The Search for Life: Are We Alone?,'' which ponders the question of life beyond Earth. and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of
title: SPARE TIMES

body: For now, there is nothing especially remarkable about the old Civil War-era warehouse on the edge of the Red Hook waterfront. But about a year from now, much of Brooklyn is expected to bound through its doors. The building, once a coffee warehouse, is about to become a Fairway supermarket, the borough's first and New York City's third. In its size
title: In Red Hook, Worries on the Waterfront

body: To the Editor: Re ''Warm and Fuzzy on the Cross Bronx'' (Jan. 27): I laughed through the comments about when you know you're a New Yorker. But it occurred to me that a ''real'' New Yorker would never even ask that question. ELIZABETH J. MILLER Gowanus, Brooklyn
title: Real New Yorkers? Don't Even Ask

author: Philip Nobel is a New York design critic.
body: EVERY major city has its essential map. Locals and tourists in Paris rely on the little red Paris par Arrondissement. In Los Angeles, no one leaves the garage without a Thomas Guide in the glove compartment. New York City is now served by a whole shelf of way-finding tools. But for 60 years, for better or for worse, the city's map of record has
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Maps Gain in Clarity But Lose a Bit of Art

body: Looking In Puck Building, Houston and Lafayette Streets; (212) 777-5218. The 10th Outsider Art Fair opens tonight with a preview to benefit the American Folk Art Museum. Tickets for admission at 5:30 p.m., $200, or, for those 40 and younger, $100; admission at 6:30, $75. The show and sale, by 33 dealers, will continue tomorrow from noon to 8 p.m.,
title: CALENDAR

body: BLOCK after block, the quiet streets of Boerum Hill, in northwest Brooklyn, are lined with shade trees and three- and four-story brick town houses, retaining the small-scale residential charm of a century ago. ''It's a well-preserved, mid-19th century brownstone community that is in the shadows of Brooklyn Heights and yet remains relatively
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Boerum Hill; Neighborhood With a 19th-Century Feel
